Each lobe of the measured far-field intensity distribution was fitted separately in the range $[q \pi / 2 - \pi / 6, q \pi / 2 + \pi / 6]$ where $q = 1, \, 2, \, 3, \, 4$ by {\mbox{Eq.~(\ref{{eq:Ifit}})}} or a corresponding expression. TE polarization was used. The envelopes of the far-field distributions are almost identical for the different symmetry classes and hence fitting the formula for another symmetry class to the experimental data yields nearly the same parameters and an equally good agreement. The effective refractive index of $n = 1.50$ was assumed to be a constant since the shape of the envelope depends very little on it, and the fits are insofar independent of $n$ as the fit yields practically the same value for ${\alpha_\mathrm{inc}}^\mathrm{(fit)} - {\alpha_{\mathrm{crit}}}$ for a wide range of values of $n$.
